column1: Little Rock is the capital and most populous city of the U.S. state of Arkansas. As the county seat of Pulaski County

column1: Little Rock derives its name from a small rock formation on the south bank of the Arkansas River called the "Little Rock" (French: La Petite Roche). The Little Rock was used by early river traffic as a landmark and became a well-known river crossing. The Little Rock is across the river from The Big Rock
column2: a large bluff at the edge of the river
column3: which was once used as a rock quarry.

column2: Bluff Dwellers
column3: and Mississippian culture peoples who built earthwork mounds recorded in 1541 by Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto. Historical tribes of the area were the Caddo

column1: Little Rock was named for a stone outcropping on the bank of the Arkansas River used by early travelers as a landmark. It was named in 1722 by French explorer and trader Jean-Baptiste Bénard de la Harpe
column2: marked the transition from the flat Mississippi Delta region to the Ouachita Mountain foothills. Travelers referred to the area as the "Little Rock." Though there was an effort to officially name the city "Arkopolis" upon its founding in the 1820s
column3: and that name did appear on a few maps made by the US Geological Survey
column4: the name Little Rock is eventually what stuck.

column1: Little Rock is located on the south bank of the Arkansas River in Central Arkansas. Fourche Creek and Rock Creek run through the city

Little Rock is home to the Arkansas Travelers. They are the AA professional Minor League Baseball affiliate of the Seattle Mariners in the Texas League. The Travelers played their last game in Little Rock at Ray Winder Field on September 3
column3: and moved into Dickey-Stephens Park in nearby North Little Rock in April 2007.

Little Rock is served by two primary Interstate Highways and four auxiliary Interstates. Interstate 40 (I-40) passes through North Little Rock to the north
column2: and I-30 enters the city from the south
column3: terminating at I-40 in the north of the Arkansas River. Shorter routes designed to accommodate the flow of urban traffic across town include I-430
column4: which bypasses the city to the west
column6: which serves the eastern part of Little Rock including Clinton National Airport
column7: and I-630 which runs east–west through the city
column8: connecting west Little Rock with the central business district. I-530 runs southeast to Pine Bluff as a spur route.U.S. Route 70 (US 70 parallels I-40 into North Little Rock before multiplexing with I-30 at the Broadway exit (exit 141B). US 67 and US 167 share the same route from the northeast before splitting. US 67 and US 70 multiplex with I-30 to the southwest. US 167 multiplexes with US 65 and I-530 to the southeast.
